title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". The Congress finds that there are over 600 different Federal financial assistance programs, some of which have duplicative or conflicting administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery at the local level. State, local, and tribal governments, along with nonprofit organizations, are facing increasingly complex problems that require coordinated services. The Congress acknowledges the need for streamlining Federal financial assistance programs to improve service delivery at the local level. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, "Federal agency" means any agency defined under section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code, and "Federal financial assistance" has the same meaning as defined in section 7501(a)(5) of title 31, United States Code. The term "non-Federal entity" refers to a State, local government, or nonprofit organization. A "nonprofit organization" is defined as any corporation, trust, association, cooperative, or other organization. A nonprofit organization is defined as a corporation, trust, association, cooperative, or other organization operated primarily for scientific, educational, service, charitable, or similar purposes in the public interest, not organized primarily for profit, and uses net proceeds to maintain, improve, or expand operations. A nonprofit organization is defined as an entity not organized primarily for profit, using net proceeds to maintain, improve, or expand operations. The term "State" includes various regions and governmental entities, while "tribal government" refers to Indian Tribal Governments. The term "tribal government" refers to Indian Tribal Governments, as defined in section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code. A "uniform administrative rule" is a government-wide rule for achieving national policy objectives across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Federal agencies must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The plan should streamline procedures for financial assistance programs, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, and designate a lead agency official. Federal agencies must designate a lead official, use a common application system, allow electronic fund applications, ensure timely reporting, and set annual goals. The Act ensures that recipients of Federal financial assistance provide high-quality information in response to reporting requirements and sets annual goals for performance measurement. If agencies cannot comply, the Director must report to the Senate and Governmental Affairs Committee. The Government Performance and Results Act requires agencies to develop and implement performance plans. If agencies are unable to comply, the Director must report to Congress and may grant extensions for up to 12 months. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for comment. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for public comment and consultation with non-Federal entities during development and implementation. Public forums on the plan should be held to the maximum extent practicable. Each Federal agency must hold public forums on the plan and consult with non-Federal entities during development and implementation. The plan developed under subsection (a) must be submitted to the Director and Congress, with annual reports on its implementation and performance. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 requires each Federal agency to submit a plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report may be included in general management reports as required by law. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes a common application for multiple programs serving similar purposes and administered by different agencies. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall establish a common system for applying, managing, and reporting on funding from multiple Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes uniform administrative rules for programs across different Federal agencies. The Director will establish a common system for managing funding from various Federal financial assistance programs, including uniform administrative rules. An interagency process will address streamlining procedures, improving coordination, and sharing data related to Federal financial assistance. The Director aims to enhance reporting requirements, interagency coordination, and data quality for Federal financial assistance programs. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to improve the timeliness, completeness, and quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies must submit information and reports to the Director for review regarding their implementation of this Act. The Director has the authority to exempt any Federal agency. (c) Review of Plans and Reports.--Agencies must provide information and reports to the Director for review on their implementation of the Act. The Director has the authority to exempt Federal agencies or financial assistance programs if they have a limited number of programs. Exempted agencies will be listed on OMB's website for public access. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness in meeting its purposes and provide recommendations for further implementation. The evaluation under subsection (a) will assess the effectiveness of the Act in meeting its purposes, evaluate agency performance, and assess coordination among various entities in implementing the Act. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Federal agencies can gather information for reviewing financial integrity or quality of services for activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

There is no judicial review of compliance with this Act, and no rights or benefits can be enforced through administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

The Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later.
